dt: {bc}an opening in a wall to let in light and air
{bc}the glass and frame that fill a window opening
{bc}any of the areas into which a computer display may be divided and on which different types of information may be shown

pt: To people living in cold regions around the world, a window in a house was only practical when glass became available to provide light while sealing out the weather. As a result, in English and other languages of northern Europe, words for {ldquo}window{rdquo} appear relatively late, after glass was introduced from southern Europe. In Old English, {ldquo}window{rdquo} was {it}ēagduru{/it}, literally {ldquo}eye-door,{rdquo} or {it}ēagthyrel{/it}, {ldquo}eye-hole{rdquo}—since a window, like an eye, is a means of seeing out. The word {it}window{/it} itself comes from a word {it}vindauga{/it} in Old Norse (the language of the Vikings) that means literally {ldquo}wind-eye.{rdquo}

shortdef: an opening in a wall to let in light and air
the glass and frame that fill a window opening
any of the areas into which a computer display may be divided and on which different types of information may be shown

dt: {bc}a large window or a set of windows that sticks out from the wall of a building
